journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of adolescent health : official publication of the Society for Adolescent Medicine

title-group.article-title: A Structural Equation Model of the Impact of a Family-Based Economic Intervention on Antiretroviral Therapy Adherence Among Adolescents Living With HIV in Uganda

article-meta.aff: aInternational Center for Child Health and Development, Brown School, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri
bDivision of Prevention Science, University of California, San Francisco, California
cInternational Center for Child Health and Development, Masaka, Uganda

fn.p: The lead PI of Suubi + Adherence study, where the manuscript was developed, is F.S.M. He also supervised the preparation of the entire manuscript. S.K., T.B.N., P.N., A.M., F.S.M., and M.M.M. contributed to the study design, while C.D., P.N., F.N., and F.S.M., participated in the data collection and oversight. Data analysis was done by S.K., T.B.N., and C.D. The manuscript was prepared by S.K. (prepared the first draft), P.N., O.S.B., and F.S.M. All authors reviewed and approved the final manuscript.

author-notes.corresp: *Address correspondence to: Fred M. Ssewamala, Ph.D., Professor, International Center for Child Health and Development, Brown School, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, MO, 63130. fms1@wustl.edu (F.M. Ssewamala).

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence among adolescents living with HIV (ALWHIV) is low, with poverty remaining a significant contributor. We examined the mediation pathways between an economic empowerment intervention and ART adherence among ALWHIV.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This cluster-randomized controlled trial (2012–2018) recruited 702 ALWHIV aged 10–16 in Uganda between January 2014 and December 2015. We randomized 39 clinics into the control (n = 344) or intervention group (n = 358). The intervention comprised a child development account, four microenterprise workshops, and 12 mentorship sessions. We used six self-reported items to measure adherence at 24 months, 36 months, and 48 months. We used structural equation modeling to assess the mediation effects through mental health and adherence self-efficacy, on adherence. We ran models corresponding to the 24, 36, and 48 months of follow-up.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The mean age of the participants was 12 years, and 56% were female. At 36 (model 2) and 48 months (model 3), the intervention had a significant indirect effect on ART adherence [B = 0.069, Β = 0.039 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.005–0.074)], and [B = 0.068, β = 0.040 (95% CI: 0.010–0.116)], respectively. In both models, there was a specific mediation effect through mental health [B = 0.070, β = 0.040 (95% CI: 0.007–0.063)], and [B = 0.039, β = 0.040 (95% CI: 0.020–0.117)]. Overall, 49.1%, 90.7%, and 36.8% of the total effects were mediated in models, 1, 2, and 3, respectively.

sec.title: Discussion:
sec.p: EE interventions improve adherence, by improving mental health functioning. These findings warrant the need to incorporate components that address mental health challenges in programs targeting poverty to improve ART adherence in low-income settings.

body.p: Globally, out of the 1.75 million adolescents aged 10–19 living with HIV, close to 90% are from Sub-Saharan Africa [1]. Sustained optimal antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence is associated with better treatment outcomes, including viral suppression, reduced accumulation of resistant HIV mutations, prolonged survival including delayed progression to AIDS stage, and reduced transmission of HIV [2]. Compared to other age categories, ART adherence among adolescents living with HIV (ALWHIV) is low [3,4]. Consequently, these adolescents have poorer treatment outcomes. ALWHIV are the only age group where the AIDS-related mortality has not reduced. In 2020 alone, 23,000 adolescents 10–19 years died from an AIDS-related cause [1].

Poverty remains a significant threat to ART adherence among ALWHIV. For instance, poverty may hinder attendance of hospital appointments [5]. Although the effect of financial constraints on ART adherence has been studied, most of the studies are among adults [6–9]. There is a paucity of literature regarding the role of economic empowerment interventions (EEIs) on ART adherence among ALWHIV in low-income settings. Moreover, the few studies testing EEIs in this population have targeted other outcomes such as, reducing HIV-related risk behavior, and improving mental health functioning [10–14]. Nonetheless, these studies have demonstrated that EEIs have a positive impact on these outcomes.

Many studies have highlighted mental health challenges as a major factor in influencing ART adherence [15,16]. Furthermore, poverty has been linked to poor mental health among the youths [12,14,17]. Children who live in poverty face many challenges such as food insecurity, low-self efficacy, school dropouts, and suboptimal care from their parents, which increase their likelihood of developing mental health challenges like depression [17,18]. To understand the relationship between poverty and mental health outcomes, Victora et al., 2022 expounded on the concept of nurturing care, which encompasses several components including child relationships, learning, security, safety, health and well-being, and nutrition [19]. The causal pathway between economic deprivation and mental health challenges is best understood through the social causation theory, which posits that socioeconomic deprivation lead to mental health challenges [20].

However, to the best of our knowledge, no study has assessed the role of mental health challenges as mediators in explaining the relationship between economic empowerment and ART adherence among ALWHIV in low-income settings. Assessing these mediator pathways is critical in understanding how economic empowerment influences ART adherence and can inform intervention development. Therefore, this study examined the mediation mechanisms through mental health functioning that explain the relationship between a family-based EEI and ART adherence among ALWHIV in a resource-restrained setting.

As illustrated in the conceptual model in Figure 1, we hypothesize that mental health challenges are mediators in the observed relationship between asset ownership and ART adherence. Specifically, family economic empowerment increases the individual and household financial stability, which positively impacts several aspects of ALWHIV, such as reducing depressive symptoms and hopelessness, and improving adherence self-efficacy, thus improving ART adherence. We based our hypothesis on the assets theory [21], which postulates that ownership of assets increases self-efficacy, creates an orientation toward the future, which leads to long-term psychosocial benefits [22]. The hypothesis also aligns with the theory of social causation that was earlier discussed [20].

sec.title: Study design and participants
sec.p: This article used the Suubi + Adherence study data, a longitudinal cluster-randomized controlled trial (2012–2018), funded by the National Institutes of Child Health and Development study (#R01HD074949–01). The study recruited 702 adolescents from 39 clinics and randomized them into the control arm (n = 19 clinics, n = 344 participants) or the intervention arm (n = 20 clinics, n = 358 participants). Participants were eligible for enrollment if they were aged 10–16 years at recruitment, medically confirmed HIV positive and aware of their status, received ART from one of the participating clinics, and lived within a family. The details are published in the study protocol [23].

sec.title: Randomization
sec.p: Forty clinics were grouped into four strata based on geographic location (rural vs. urban) and health clinic level (health center vs. hospital). The clinics were then randomized into intervention and control groups, with each group allocated 20 clinics. However, one clinic belonging to the treatment arm was dropped due to a lack of required government registration. To limit contamination, all participants in each clinic received the same intervention, corresponding to the study arm to which the clinic was randomized.

sec.title: Intervention
sec.p: Participants in the intervention arm of the study received the intervention, which comprised three components:

list-item.p: Child development account. A long-term savings account was opened for each study participant, in which they saved their money. The Suubi + Adherence study made the initial deposit of money on the account. In addition, for each monthly deposit that the participant saved in the account, the study added an equal amount. These accounts were retained by the participants upon the termination of the study. Various studies have shown the positive role of child development accounts in improving adolescent mental health functioning [12,14,24,25].

Workshops. The participants and their families participated in microenterprise workshops where they were trained on financial management and starting family businesses. A total of four sessions were provided per participant.

The participants received mentorship through attending 12 educational sessions. These sessions addressed various topics, including setting short- and long-term goals, averting risk-taking behaviors, and business development.

sec.p: Details about the intervention have been published elsewhere [11,12,23]. A separate analysis from this study showed that the intervention embraced by the participants and resulted in significant accumulation of savings [26]. The intervention was provided in addition to the bolstered standard of care that all ALWHIV received. Participants in the control group received a bolstered standard of care package, which included both medical and psychosocial care. ALWHIV were treated according to the Uganda Ministry of Health HIV/AIDS treatment guidelines [27]. Although ART adherence counseling is part of routine care for ALWHIV, its frequency and quality vary. Our team offered six adherence sessions to all the ALWHIV enrolled in the study to standardize adherence counseling, including those in the control arm.

sec.title: Outcome.
sec.p: The primary outcome was ART adherence, measured using a six-item self-report measure, three of which are included in the Wilson’s three-item self-reported adherence measurement [28]. We used this measure because using one question to measure self-reported adherence overestimates adherence because of the social desirability and recall biases [28]. Moreover, self-reported adherence is a strong predictor of viral suppression, and its performance is comparable to that of more objective measures of adherence, such as pill counts and electronic adherence measures [29–31]. Adherence data were collected at 24, 36, and 48 months postintervention initiation, with Cronbach’s alpha ranging from 0.43 at baseline to 0.49 at 48 months. Specifically, participants were asked six questions as elaborated below.

list-item.p: “When was the last time you missed your medication?” (1 = never, 2 = < one week, 3 = 1–2 weeks, 4 = 2–4 weeks, 5 = 1–3 months, and 6 over 3 months).
“In the last 30 days, on how many days did you miss at least one dose of your HIV medications?” Response was number of days ranging from 0 to 30.
In the last 30 days, how often did you take your HIV medicine in the way you were supposed to? (1 = never, 2 = rarely, 3 = sometimes, 4 = usually, and 5 = always).
How hard is it for you to take your HIV medicines in the way you are supposed to? (responses ranged from 1 = extremely hard to 5 = not hard at all).
How often do you argue with the person helping you to take you medicine? (1 = never, 2 = rarely, 3 = sometimes, 4 = usually, and 5 = always).
In general, in the last six months, how often did you miss taking your medication? (1 = always, 2 = I miss taking most, 3 = I miss taking half, 4 = I miss taking a little bit, and 5 = I never miss).

sec.p: Without categorizing any item, the six measurements were used as indicators in the structural equation modeling to create a latent variable for adherence. Table 1 shows the self-reported adherence of the participants at 24, 36, and 48 months. We treated the measures as continuous because changes in adherence that occur below the optimal adherence levels could have clinical and public health implications.

sec.title: Mediators.
sec.p: In our analysis, the mediators included mental health functioning and adherence self-efficacy.

sec.title: Mental health functioning.
sec.p: We determined mental health functioning using depression, hopelessness, and self-concept.

list-item.p: Depressive symptoms: We used the 14-item (a short version of the 27-item) Children’s Depression Inventory to assess depressive symptoms. The 14-item Children’s Depression Inventory has been validated and used in studies among the same population (alpha = 0.63) [32].

Hopelessness was measured using Beck’s Hopelessness Scale, a 20-item score (True or False) that assessed a participant’s attitude toward the future. The total scores ranged between 0 and 20 with higher scores indicating more hopelessness (alpha = 0.73) [14].

Self-concept was measured using a 17-item short version of the Tennessee Self-Concept Scale (100-items) that has items scored on a five-point Likert scale. We added responses for each participant to create a total score (alpha = 0.75) [14].

sec.title: Adherence self-efficacy.
sec.p: We used the adherence self-efficacy scale that has 12 questions which assess the adolescent’s confidence in adhering to prescribed medication [33]. Each question has a score ranging from 1 to 10, and higher values represent high self-efficacy (alpha = 0.92). The scale has been previously used to measure adherence self-efficacy in the same population [34].

We also collected baseline information including the participants’ age, gender, education level, orphanhood status (non-orphan vs. single orphan vs. double orphan), the years ALWHIV has lived with HIV, and the ART regimen that the participant is taking.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: Analysis was done using Stata Version 17 and Mplus 8.1 [35]. We performed cluster-adjusted comparisons of baseline demographic, clinical characteristics, and ART adherence between the two study groups. To account for within-class correlation, we used the Pearson adjustment method to calculate chi-square statistics. We summarized continuous variables using means and standard deviations, while we used percentages for categorical variables. We reported summary statistics for the entire sample and across the two subgroups.

To test the intervention’s direct, indirect, and total effect on ART adherence, we used MPlus software to fit structural equation modeling, while preserving the temporal order of events (the intervention preceded the mediators, which also preceded the outcome). Specifically, the mediators were measured two years after the intervention initiation, and the outcomes were assessed two (model 1), three (model 2), and four years (model 3) after intervention initiation. Prior to fitting the structural model, we fitted separate measurement models for self-concept, hopelessness, depression, adherence self-efficacy, mental health latent construct, and ART adherence. We achieved good model fitness for all the measurement models (see Table 1). Overall, we performed three models, while controlling for the effect of the participants’ age and sex on the mediators and outcome. As illustrated in Figure 2, path a illustrates the effect of the intervention on the mediators, while path b shows the effect of the mediators on ART adherence [36,37]. The indirect effect of the intervention on ART adherence is a*b. The direct effect of the intervention on ART adherence (in absence of mediators) is c’. The total effect of the intervention on ART adherence is denoted c and is the sum of the direct and indirect effects (c = c’+a*b) [36]. Model 1 assessed the impact of economic empowerment on ART adherence at 24 months, while other models assessed the intervention’s impact at 36 and 48 months. We reported cluster-adjusted robust standard errors of our estimates. In all our models, we adjusted for age and gender. We reported the non-standardized coefficients (B), and the standardized coefficients (β) and their Huber-White cluster (clinic)-adjusted 95% confidence intervals, and significance levels were set at p = .05, after 1,000 bootstrapped sample replicates. In addition, we also calculated the chi-square test of goodness of fit, Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA), the Comparative Fit Index (CFI), and the Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR) to determine the overall goodness of fit of our final models. Specifically, we aimed for a statistically nonsignificant chi-square test to determine the exact model fit, or else, CFI of at least 0.95, RMSEA of less than 0.06, or SRMR of less than 0.08 to denote a good model [38]. As recommended by Hu and Bentler, meeting any one of the criteria would be considered good model fitness [39].

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: Both Makerere University School of Public Health Research and Ethics committee (Protocol #210) and the Uganda National Council for Science and Technology (UNCST, SS 2969) reviewed and approved the study protocol. Also, the study was approved by the Columbia University Review Board (AAAK3852). The Suubi + Adherence study is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (#NCT01790373). Participation in the study was voluntary. All adolescents provided written assent, and their caregivers provided written informed consent for their adolescents to participate in the study. We sought for the assent separately, away from the caregivers, to prevent coercion. The study staff received Good Clinical Practice (GCP) or online Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative (CITI) ethics training.

sec.title: Baseline characteristics of the study participants
sec.p: Baseline characteristics of the adolescents are summarized in Table 2. Overall, 344 of the 702 adolescents were randomized into the control group, while 358 were assigned to the intervention group. The mean age of the participants was 12 years (range: 10–16 years), and 56% of the adolescents were female. Slightly more than one-quarter of the participants (26%) were double orphans, and 13% were not enrolled in school at baseline. A total of 438 adolescents (62%) were on the first-line treatment regimen. As shown in Table 3, at baseline, the participants’ overall adherence was 81.7% (78.7%–84.4%), with higher adherences in the intervention 82.1% (77.7%–85.7%) than control groups 81.4% (76.9%–85.2%).

sec.title: Direct and indirect effect of the intervention
sec.p: All three models showed that participating in the intervention significantly reduced the mental health challenges, and that reduced mental health challenges improved treatment adherence. Also, models 2 and 3 showed significant indirect effect of the intervention on adherence, although none of the models showed significant direct or total effects of the intervention on the outcome. These results suggest full mediation, where the intervention only has indirect mediation effect on adherence through mental health functioning.

At 24 months, there was no mediation effect detected. The direct, indirect, and total effects of the intervention on adherence were not statistically significant. The proportion of the total effect mediated was 49.1% (Table 4, Figure 3).

At 36 months, the intervention had a statistically significant indirect effect on ART adherence [B = 0.069, β = 0.039 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.005–0.074)]. There was a specific mediation effect through mental health [B = 0.070, β = 0.040 (95% CI: 0.007–0.063)]. In this model, 90.7% of the total effect was due to mediation. In this model, the direct and total effects of the intervention were non-significant (Table 4, Figure 4). We achieved good model fitness with CFI = 0.916, RMSEA = 0.024, and SRMR = 0.056.

Similarly, at 48 months, we found statistically significant indirect effect of the EE intervention on ART adherence, through mental health [B = 0.068, β = 0.040 (95% CI: 0.010–0.116)]. There was a specific mediation effect through mental health [B = 0.039, β = 0.040 (95% CI: 0.020–0.117)]. In model 3, 36.8% of the total effect was due to mediation. In this model, the direct and total effects of the intervention were non-significant (Table 4, Figure 5). We achieved good model fitness with CFI = 0.919, RMSEA = 0.024, and SRMR = 0.056 (Table 5).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This article examined the mediation pathways explaining the effects of a family-based EEI—which consisted of a savings bank account, financial literacy workshops for the adolescent and the family, and peer mentorship—on self-reported ART adherence among ALWHIV in an income-constrained setting. Our findings showed that the intervention had a significant indirect effect—through mental health functioning—in improving ART adherence among ALWHIV at 36 months and 48 months of follow-up.

As hypothesized, our intervention indirectly improved ART adherence by reducing mental distress. These results contribute to our understanding of the influence of economic deprivation on ART adherence. While several studies suggested a direct relationship between poverty and poor adherence[5,40]—for instance, lack money for transport to keep up with treatment appointments at the hospital and sustain a healthy diet [5,14]—we have demonstrated that by addressing poverty (through asset accumulation) ALWHIV indirectly improved their adherence through reduced mental distress. Moreover, previous studies documented direct effects of poverty on psychological distress [12,14,41] and poor mental health functioning on hindering adherence. For instance, Dorothy Dow et al. found suboptimal adherence to ART among HIV-positive adolescents in Tanzania, and suggested depression as one of the contributing factors [42]. Similar findings were reported in a mixed-methods study among Zambian HIV-positive adolescents [43]. Therefore, it is not surprising that by addressing poverty the participants’ mental health and subsequently their adherence to art were improved. Economic empowerment addresses poverty and its effects, hence improving the mental health functioning of the ALWHIV [21]. These findings support the asset theory [21], which posits that ownership of assets improves the psychosocial well-being and is associated with better health outcomes [44]. This improves their attitude toward treatment adherence.

Our study is among the few studies to assess the mediation mechanisms of a family-based EEI through mental health functioning and adherence self-efficacy on ART adherence among adolescents in low-income settings. In conclusion, we found that economic empowerment improves ART adherence through reducing mental distress. Our results support the theory that economic empowerment improves patient key outcomes and demonstrate that financial savings, financial literacy, and peer mentorship can play a crucial role in improving treatment adherence. These findings warrant the need for incorporating economic empowerment components and enhanced psychological support in HIV care programs in low-income settings.

A significant strength of our study is that we employed a longitudinal randomized controlled design with robust methodologies and followed up participants for five years, which is long enough to examine the short- and mid-term effects of our interventions. Via temporal ordering of the intervention exposure, mediators, and outcome, the longitudinal design also enables us to strengthen the rigor of the associations between our intervention and adherence. The study used detailed, reliable, and validated multi-item tools for measuring key variables. However, our study had some limitations. We measured adherence using self-reports, which are prone to recall and social desirability biases. Consequently, despite self-report being widely used in many published studies, it overestimates adherence. However, we used six self-reported adherence items and generated a latent construct, which is more robust and corrects most of these biases [28]. We recommend studies that assess ART adherence using more objective measures. Finally, although we tested mediation effects of mental health functioning, it is probable that other pathways could be responsible for influencing the relationship between economic empowerment and ART adherence, for instance, family and social support. We recommend more studies to study other mediation pathways for the relationship between economic empowerment and adherence.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We extend our thanks to the adolescents who voluntarily participated in this study alongside their families. We also thank Reach the Youth-Uganda (RYT), Masaka diocese, and the study clinics, with whom we partnered during the study. We, finally thank the ICHAD team in Masaka, Uganda for coordinating the field activities that were crucial for successfully implementing the study.

sec.title: Funding Sources
sec.p: Funding for the Suubi + Adherence study, from which this article was conceived, was provided by the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institutes of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD), grant number 1R01HD074949-01(PI: Fred M. Ssewamala). The contents of this manuscript are solely the responsibility of the authors and do not necessarily represent the official views of NICHD. The funders had no role in the preparing this manuscript.

fn.p: Conflicts of interest: The authors have no conflicts of interest to disclose.

Disclaimer: This article was published as part of a supplement supported by the National Institute of Mental Health. The opinions or views expressed in this article are those of the authors and do not necessarily represent the official position of the funder.

sec.title: Data availability:
sec.p: On reasonable request, the data sets included in this analysis are available from the corresponding author.

caption.p: Structural equation models examining the effect of an economic empowerment intervention on ART adherence among HIV-positive adolescents

ART = antiretroviral therapy; Cl = confidence interval.

fn.p: CFI = Comparative Fit Index; RMSEA = Root Mean Square Error of Approximation; SRMR, Standardized Root Mean Square Residual; TLI = Tucker-Lewis index.

boxed-text.p: These results show that economic empowerment improves mental functioning of HIV-infected adolescents, which subsequently improves treatment adherence. These findings have the potential to change clinical practice, thinking about care, and can inform future guideline and policy formulation for HIV-positive adolescents in low-resource settings.
